title.english: Star Blazers: The Quest for Iscandar

description:
In the distant future, the war between the human race and the Gamilon has taken its toll on the planet Earth. Constant bombardment of radioactive asteroids has rendered the planet's atmosphere uninhabitable. As a means of relief aid, Queen Starsha of the planet Iscandar offers the Earth Forces a device that can completely neutalize the radiation off the planet. For this task, the space battleship Yamato is launched from the remains of its World War II ancestor on a 148,000 light-year journey. However, the crew of the Yamato has only one Earth year to travel to Iscandar and back, or the human race will come to an end.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Space Opera
tags.description: Centers around space warfare, advanced technology, chivalric romance and adventure.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Ships
tags.description: Prominently features the use of sea-based transportation vessels.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

name.native: スターシャ・イスカンダル

node.description:
An animator turned mangaka, Yasuhiko was born in Hokkaido in December 1947, he dropped out of Hirosaki University in 1970 to work for MushiPro as an animator. In the 70s he became a freelancer and worked on TV anime. Some of his most famous work as a character designer or director are "Space Battleship Yamato", "Brave Raideen", "Combattler V" and "Mobile Suit Gundam".

In 1979, he made his debut as a mangaka with "Arion" serialized in the newly founded magazine "Ryu". Following this, Yasuhiko alternated between the Anime and Manga worlds with works like "Kiba - The Legend of White Fang", "Crusher Joe", and "Giant Gorg", and "Star of the Kurds", "C-Court", and "Venus Wars".

These worlds would overlap, when his manga "Arion" would get adapted into an anime film in 1986 with the title "Neo Heroic Fantasia: Arion". Following this, he would adapt his SF Military Chronicle "Venus Wars" into an anime film in 1989. The anime film adaptation for "Venus Wars" came at an unfortunate point for Yasuhiko, and the film was sealed, preventing it from being made readily available on home video formats in Japan (though still made accessible overseas). He turned to manga completely and had gained a respectable reputation as a history mangaka with works focusing on both Japanese history with "Jinmu", "Namuji", "Yamato Takeru" and European history with "Alexandros", "Joan", and Theology with "Jesus".

In 2001 he adapted the First Gundam anime into a manga with "Mobile Suit Gundam: The Origin" and was colossally popular, being serialized for 24 Tankoban volumes.

With over 50 years worth of experience across multiple mediums of entertainment and showing no signs of stopping, Yasuhiko's terrific worldview continues to touch the hearts of many around the world.

In 1981, he won the Seiun Award in the Art category. In 1992, he received the Japan Cartoonists Association Award for his work "Namuji". From 1979 to 1982, he ranked first in the Anime Grand Prix for Character Design. In 2000, he won the Japan Media Arts Festival Excellence Prize in the Manga category for "Ōdō no Inu". In 2012, he won the Seiun Award in the Best Comic category for "Mobile Suit Gundam: The Origin". In 2015, he received the Animation Kobe Special Award.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/富野由悠季) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshiyuki_Tomino)

Yoshiyuki Tomino is an anime creator best known for creating the Gundam anime franchise.

Began his career in 1963 with [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s company, [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/), scripting and directing episodes of the first Japanese anime television series, [Astro Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/). He later became one of the most important members of the anime studio [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), going on to direct numerous anime through the '70s, '80s and '90s. He is perhaps best known for his transformation of the "Super Robot" mecha anime genre into the "Real Robot" genre with 1979's [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/), the first in the Gundam franchise.

Known for using numerous pseudonyms.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/leijimatsumoto)

Matsumoto's art might take some getting used to, but he is renowned for coming up with great stories and brilliant new concepts. Debuting in 1953 with a 16 page manga "Mitsubachi no Bouken" in Manga Shounen, he has authored nearly thirty manga series.

His big break came in 1971, in the years between 53 and 71 he mostly produced Shoujo manga, much to his displeasure. In the late '70s and the early '80s, there was a big Matsumoto-boom when he drew his best known series. After that, things became more quiet around him, but the late '90s show a revival.

The trademarks of Matsumoto are his unusual artstyle, the space opera and the manly romance stories.

In 1997, Matsumoto began to create new adventures of Captain Harlock which can be admired on the Web in Japanese and in English.

One of Matsumoto Reiji's former assistants is [Sennou Knife](https://anilist.co/staff/99382), who was also an assistant of [Maki Miyako](https://anilist.co/staff/114821/). He went solo in the mid-80s and enjoyed modest success with Yami no Silhouette.

His real name is Matsumoto Akira. Reiji is a pseudonym and means something like "Zero Warrior". His name is often rendered in romaji as "Matsumoto Leiji". Matsumoto is married to Maki Miyako.

He died of heart failure on February 13, 2023 in a hospital in Tokyo.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/leijimatsumoto)

Matsumoto's art might take some getting used to, but he is renowned for coming up with great stories and brilliant new concepts. Debuting in 1953 with a 16 page manga "Mitsubachi no Bouken" in Manga Shounen, he has authored nearly thirty manga series.

His big break came in 1971, in the years between 53 and 71 he mostly produced Shoujo manga, much to his displeasure. In the late '70s and the early '80s, there was a big Matsumoto-boom when he drew his best known series. After that, things became more quiet around him, but the late '90s show a revival.

The trademarks of Matsumoto are his unusual artstyle, the space opera and the manly romance stories.

He died of heart failure on February 13, 2023 in a hospital in Tokyo.

Yoshinobu Nishizaki was best known as the co-creator of Space Battleship Yamato. He was born in 1934 and graduated from Nihon University Art Department.

In 1994 he designed Yamato 2520. But in the end he was sued by Matsumoto Leiji for breach of copyright. Since then he has been arrested for gun and drug offences. Later in 2002 the court ruled that Nishizaki was the original author and owner of the copyright for Uchuu Senkan Yamato. Matsumoto appealed but settled out of court in 2003 in agreement that Nishizaki was the author.

He passed away on November 7th, 2010 at the age of 75 when he fell from a research steamboat, named Yamato, to the sea near Chichijima island and drowned.

(Source: AniDB)

A highly prolific and an extremely influential animator.

Know for his experimentation with the timing of keyframes, his dynamic poses, and his peculiar effects Kanada pioneered a number of techniques and concepts that permeated and shaped the Japanese animation industry, influencing not only his peers but also the generations to come.

Kanada's ability and his tendency to be very personal with his drawings, even to the point of ignoring storyboards if the situation required, popularized in the industry the concept of letting the individual animator's talents shine instead of being uniformed into anonymity. This precept is still respected today and it's one of the reasons Japanese animation is so distinctly unique. His career is also a testament to his ethos that expressive and vibrant animation is not achieved simply through increasing the number of frames but through playing with movement, poses and timing.

In the early '00s, Kanada became an employee at Square Enix.

Notable Square Enix titles in which he was credited:

~!
- 2002, Final Fantasy XI (Motion Capture, Animation Director)
- 2005, Musashiden II: Blade Master (Storyboard)
- 2006, Dawn of Mana (Facial Setting)
- 2007, Final Fantasy 4 DS Version (Storyboard)
- 2009, Final Fantasy XIII (Storyboard Director) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2011, Final Fantasy XIII-2 (Storyboard) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2012, Dragon Quest X (Storyboard)  - *Posthumous credit.* !~

Composer of various games and anime, notably Space Battleship Yamato.

Died of heart failure at the age of 75 on March 21, 2006.

[Wiki (JP)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/芦田豊雄)

Toyoo Ashida was an anime character designer, animation director and director. He is the founder of the anime production studio Studio Live and as well as the Japanese Animation Creators Association (JAniCA) along with [Satoshi Kon](https://anilist.co/staff/99580/).

He is also known under the pseudonyms Yutaka Ekoda (江古田豊) and Monta Ibu (伊武紋太).

[Wiki (JP)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/芦田豊雄)

Toyoo Ashida was an anime character designer, animation director and director. He is the founder of the anime production studio Studio Live and as well as the Japanese Animation Creators Association (JAniCA) along with [Satoshi Kon](https://anilist.co/staff/99580/).

He is also known under the pseudonyms Yutaka Ekoda (江古田豊) and Monta Ibu (伊武紋太).

[Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noboru_Ishiguro) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/石黒昇)

Noboru Ishiguro was noteworthy for directing classic anime series like [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/), [Orguss](https://anilist.co/anime/2089/) and [Legend of the Galactic Heroes](https://anilist.co/anime/820/).

He was in a Hawaiian-style music band in his youth. Therefore, he is known as an animation director who can actually read musical scores and has made the best use of his previous experience for works such as [Macross: Do You Remember Love?](https://anilist.co/anime/1089/) and Legend of the Galactic Heroes. He entered Nihon University in the Department of Art and graduated in 1964. He joined Onishi Pro where he first worked as a key animator on subcontracted Astro Boy episodes. In 1978, he founded [Artland](https://anilist.co/studio/8/) for which he served as an executive director until he passed away in 2012.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/leijimatsumoto)

He died of heart failure on February 13, 2023 in a hospital in Tokyo.
Sadafumi Sano is a director of photography.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/内山正幸)

Passed away due to a heart failure on August 31, 2010.

__Birth Place:__ Shimane Prefecture, Japan

Okasako Nobuhiro is an animator, character designer and director. 

He entered Toei Douga in 1958 and has since gone through Mushi Production, Nippon Housou Douga (日本放送動画) and Tsuchida Production. In 1987 he established the animation studio Studio Victory and became its representative.
